_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is to inform all interested persons, including employees that Darling Ingredients, Inc. is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (called Process Safety Management or PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (called RM Program), Title 40 CFR Part 68, to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and processing of hazardous chemicals, In this way we promote overall plant, worker, and public safety.  These programs enable our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.   Overall, these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.  Our safety programs are applied to any activity involving hazardous chemicals including any use, storage, manufacturing, handling, or the on-site movement of such chemicals, or combination of these activities.  Any group of vessels which are interconnected and separate vessels which are located such that a hazardous chemical could be involved in a potential release shall be considered a single process.  

Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices which govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and improved as necessary.  They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at the facility.  Darling Ingredients, Inc.' plan to improve safety are conducting yearly evacuation drills and offer continual training for operators.

Darling Ingredients, Inc. in Ravenna, NE is a pet food processing facility. The facility operates two ammonia refrigeration systems located at the North end and the South end of the building.  The total anhydrous ammonia inventory in this single process is 25,700 lbs.

The North System is operated as a two-stage system

.  On the low stage portion of the system, a low temperature accumulator operating at -40°F pumps liquid to plate freezers located in the processing room.  The plate freezers are designed to freeze pet food.  The low temperature ammonia liquid flows across the freezer plates where it picks up heat from the product, changing the ammonia from a liquid to a vapor.  The low-pressure ammonia vapor is sent from the plate freezers to the accumulator via a suction header.

Vapor from the low temperature accumulator is fed to low stage compressors. The compressed vapor from the low stage compressors is sent to an intercooler operating at +15°F. 

Vapor from the intercooler is then fed to the high stage compressors.  During the compression phase in the high stage compressors, the temperature of the ammonia vapor will rise as the pressure of the ammonia vapor is increased to approximately 150-180 psig psig. The high-pressure ammonia vapor flows from the high stage compressors to an evaporative condenser where heat is removed, turning the vapor into a high pressure liquid.  The high-pressure liquid is collected in a high-pressure receiver.  The liquid collected in the high-pressure receiver provides liquid make-up for the intercooler and for the low temperature accumulator.

The South Engine Room is operated as three single stage systems. In the System #2 portion of the South Engine Room, a high temperature accumulator operating at +15°F pumps liquid to Cooler #1, Alcove, North Dock and South Dock evaporators.  The +15°F ammonia liquid flows across the various coils where it picks up heat from the product, changing the ammonia from a liquid to a vapor.  The low-pressure ammonia vapor is sent from the evaporators to the system #2 accumulator via a suction header.

Vapor from the +15°F accumulator is fed to high stage compressors. The compressed vapor from the high stage compressors is sent to the South Engine Room condensers.

In the System #3 portion of the South Engi

ne Room, a low temperature accumulator operating at -30°F pumps liquid to North and South Freezer evaporators.  The -30°F ammonia liquid flows across the various coils where it picks up heat from the product, changing the ammonia from a liquid to a vapor.  The low-pressure ammonia vapor is sent from the evaporators to the system #3 accumulator via a suction header.

Vapor from the -30°F accumulator is fed to low stage compressors. The compressed vapor from the low stage compressors is sent to the South Engine Room condensers.

In the System #4 portion of the South Engine Room, a high temperature accumulator operating at +20°F pumps liquid to the processing room rooftop units and Cooler #2.  The +20°F ammonia liquid flows across the coils and evaporators where it picks up heat from the product, changing the ammonia from a liquid to a vapor.  The low-pressure ammonia vapor is sent from the coils and evaporators to the system #4 accumulator via a suction header.

Vapor from the +20°F accumulator is fed to high stage compressors. The compressed vapor from the high stage compressors is sent to the South Engine Room condensers.

During the compression phase in all of the South Engine Room compressors, the temperature of the ammonia vapor will rise as the pressure of the ammonia vapor is increased to approximately 150 -180 psig. The high pressure ammonia vapor flows from the compressors, to the evaporative condensers where heat is removed, turning the vapor into a liquid. The high pressure liquid is collected in the high pressure receiver. The liquid collected in the high-pressure receiver provides liquid make-up for the intercooler and for the low temperature accumulator.

The emergency action plan at Darling Ingredients, Inc. requires all associates to be trained in safe evacuation and notification procedures in cases of actual or drill emergencies. Training shall include escape routes, notification of appropriate response agencies, instructions on activating a

building fire alarm system and what should be done after evacuating a building. To aid in the training process evacuation drills are conducted at the facility.  In the case of an emergency, Kevin Bosshamer is the plant manager and is the Incident Commander. The alternate Incident Commander is the Roger Larson, Maintenance Manager.  The Manager of Environmental Affairs, Dan Kilkenny, will coordinate Darling's Emergency Action Plan and applicable emergency services with the following local agencies:

Kearney Emergency Management
308-233-3225

Ravenna Police Department
308-452-4145

Ravenna Fire Department
308-452-4373

Upon discovering an emergency situation, all employees shall immediately notify their lead person, supervisor, or the Maintenance Department using the phone, radio, or wireless phones. The lead person or supervisor of the affected area, Human Resources, or maintenance personnel are to contact the Primary Incident Commander (IC). If the Primary IC is not available, the alternate IC shall be notified next.  The IC will determine if evacuation of the plant is the safest course of action and should activate the evacuation alarm if necessary.  If the emergency involves the release of ammonia and a decision is made to evacuate the plant, first determine the assembly area.  The location of the assembly area will be based on the current wind direction and will be upwind of the release area.   The use of a blow horn and/or alarm horn/strobe will inform employees that they are to evacuate the building.  If your immediate contact options cannot be reached, dial 911.  In the event of an evacuation, all employees should proceed to the designated assembly area and await further instructions from their evacuation supervisor. Facility map identifying exit doors, evacuation routes and assembly areas are posted at various locations throughout the facility.  Once everyone has evacuated the facility and arrived at their designated meeting area, a head count mus

t be conducted by the evacuation coordinators to account for missing people, including visitors and/or contractors in his/her area.  A daily crew/employee list shall be maintained for each department within the facility. Ten minutes will be allowed for critical unit operators to shutdown their equipment and reach the designated meeting location before attendance will be reported.  

Regarding the worst case scenario assessment, the North Engine Room has a maximum intended inventory of 14,364 lbs completely full.  The worst case scenario is assuming the maximum charge of ammonia in the North Engine Room is released.  If the entire charge were to release within 10 minutes, the distance to endpoint of the release would be 1.46 miles.

The scenario of a worst case ammonia release is unlikely due to the following reasons:

1.	Worst-case weather conditions are uncommon.
2.	Industry standards for the manufacture and quality control of pressure vessels.
3.	Ammonia is not corrosive in this service.
4.	Pressure safety valves limit operating pressure in this vessel.
5.	Installed ammonia sensors in the engine room to warn of leaks.
6.	The emergency response plan in place at the facility.

Darling Ingredients, Inc. has not had any accidents to report since the commissioning of this plant in 2015.
